First off, hello everyone!.  I've got about 1300 hours or so in the game (if steam is right), but it's almost entirely self-taught minus a few forums, mods, and Scott Manley :).

I mention this because with anything self-taught, it's easy to bypass something fundamental which may have answered this question, so apologies if it's stupid obvious...

On to the issue:  Using 4 nuclear engines on a 30ton "Shuttle" designed to run back and forth between Mun, Minmus and LKO.  DeltaV is around 6K.  the 30tons is dry, somewhere over 70tons w/fuel.  Maneuvering burns takes for ever and I'm missing my ideal positions all over the place.  I do split the burn times, but when you're burning 2-3 mins total, burning 1-1.5 minutes before and after mark messes up your planned path/location.

So, obviously a higher thrust engine shortens burn time at the expense of fuel economy, but is there an 'ideal' thrust per ton that I might want to shoot for, for SOI maneuvering?

First of all, welcome to the forums!

I had the same question too, but right now I'm kinda into some other stuff, namely getting to orbit from Eve. Anyway, Lets say I am in your situation, namely LKO. I want to burn out to Minmus. First, make a maneuver, and use the little icon that shows up to set it to the next orbit. Then, get it to go out to Minmus' altitude, don't bother with the plane change.  On the first pass burn about half of the deltaV, then when you get to the next orbit around, finish it up. You should have a close approach marker. As you head out, there will be an AN or DN marker, so make a trim maneuver there.you can adjust your inclination here to save deltaV and burn time, and make any other adjustment as necessary.  This 'trim manuver' should be only 75-125 m/s to save burn time, and hopefully it will be a lot more accurate as well.

Hope this helps!

+1 to batman's advice about doing the burn in multiple passes, if necessary.

That said:  I do burns like this all the time, in just a single pass.  As long as the burn's no longer than around 3 minutes or so, it's not that big of a deal.  I just split the burn across the node, half-before and half-after, and it gets me pretty close to where I want to go.  Sometimes I'll stop after doing about 95% of the burn, clear the node, and then place a new node to do a bit of correction to take up the slack.

If the burn is significantly longer than 3 minutes, then I'll typically do it in a couple of passes.

Batman78781,

So, if I'm understanding, you do a half maneuver, then wait until you reach the same point again and complete the burn.  Minmus will have changed positions, but if I'm understanding this right, you're suggesting an adjustment at the AN or DN to compensate for that difference and use the opportunity to adjust plane as well?  If I've gotten that right, then I can see the sense in it.  If not, then I'm in more trouble than I thought lol.  Thanks, I'll give that a shot!

 

Between your comment and Snark's, it appears that upsizing the engine, while it SHOULD complete the burns faster, isn't worth the fuel consumption.  Is that a fair assessment?

Bearing in mind that there's only a delay of an hour (two at most) from your first burn to your second, and Minmus really doesn't move very far in that length of time.  It takes weeks for Minmus to make a circuit of Kerbin.  So yes, an adjustment, but it won't be much of one.

18 minutes ago, mghal9k said:

Between your comment and Snark's, it appears that upsizing the engine, while it SHOULD complete the burns faster, isn't worth the fuel consumption.  Is that a fair assessment?

Yes-- engines = dead weight = bad.  You always want as little engine as you can get away with, while maintaining the TWR that you need for a mission.

Ships that have to lift from a planet have to have at least a certain amount of TWR or they can't get up to orbit, so that puts a practical lower limit.  However, for ships that are already in orbit, you can get by with a very low TWR, so less engine is better.  Particularly for engines as heavy as LV-N's.

2 hours ago, mghal9k said:

Between your comment and Snark's, it appears that upsizing the engine, while it SHOULD complete the burns faster, isn't worth the fuel consumption.  Is that a fair assessment?

In first approximation, yes. There's two limiting factors, though:

  1. your patience
  2. dV expenditure on interplanetary burns.

1) should be obvious, but I'll briefly elaborate about 2): you can't accumulate more than ~950m/s in Kerbin orbit. If you want to go to (say) Jool, you will need another ~1100m/s on top of that, and this *has* to happen in one single pass. The longer that burn takes, the more inefficient it becomes. If you want to do it the usual way (just put down one maneuver and execute it) the magic threshold is somewhere around 0.15-0.2g -- if your ship has less acceleration, your maneuver will be so wasteful that adding another engine will actually save fuel despite the increased mass.

Pretty much, but not quite. Here's a picture: You see those two little blue buttons? They let you move the node forward one orbit, or back one orbit if possible. I mean to plan the burn 1 orbit ahead, execute part of it oon the same orbit [ie: one orbit before the node] , and then do the rest at the next pass. with this, even the mun will not move a lot off where you planned, only the lag time from the longer orbit before the final execution. Then, a course correction and inclination change at the AN or DN, or in the mun's case, a course correction as soon as you can do it. Course corrections are more efficient the further you are, but inclination changes only hit right on the mark at AN/DN. In minmus' case, its just more convenient to do the course correction along with the inc change unless you feel like messing with multiple nodes to plot your course. P.S. The picture is only to show the blue buttons under the node. It doesnt show how to execute the burn or anything!!! Thought the mun encounter would confuse people XD.

 .

Now if you'll excuse me, I need to get back to SB50! Typing this during a commercial break
